meaning: 的 (de) is a very common structural particle. meaning: A common, polite expression used to apologize, to say you are sorry, or to get someone’s attention in a respectful way. It can express regret for causing trouble, making a mistake, bumping into someone, or letting someone down emotionally or practically.

不: ⿱一③ — A top stroke 一 over a complex lower part, historically meaning “no; not; negative.” It blocks or negates what follows.
起: ⿺走巳 — The walking/running radical 走 plus 巳 (a curled shape, also a zodiac sign), together giving the sense of starting to move, rise, or get up.
Putting it together: 对 (toward) + 不 (not) + 起 (rise) → “cannot face you / cannot lift my head toward you,” so I feel sorry and apologize.

meaning: 来 (lái) primarily means “to come,” indicating movement toward the speaker or a reference point. It can act as a main verb (to come), a directional complement (e.g., 回来 come back), or a substitute for another verb (我来 do it, I’ll do it). It also appears in time expressions meaning “ever since” or “for the past …” (自古以来 since ancient times, 三年来 for the past three years), and as a prefix meaning “the coming/next …” (来世 next life). Between two verbs, it can mean “in order to” (想来看看 want to come and see). After 得 or 不, it indicates possibility or impossibility (谈得来 get along; 吃不来 can’t get used to eating).
components: 来 is now written in its simplified form and also serves as the traditional form. Historically, it depicted a plant or wheat with drooping heads, but in modern usage it’s treated as a single indivisible character (no separate semantic radical + phonetic part in everyday learning). Just remember its overall shape: a short top stroke, a central vertical line, and crossing strokes below, like a small plant or figure moving toward you.

meaning: 了 has two main readings. As “le”, it is a very common grammatical particle: (1) after a verb, it marks a completed action or new situation (“I ate already”), and (2) at the end of a sentence, it often signals a change of state or a new situation (“It’s cold now”). It can also add emphasis to what comes before. As “liǎo”, it means to finish or manage to do something, especially in patterns with 得 or 不 (e.g. 受得了 ‘can stand it’, 受不了 ‘cannot stand it’), and also “to understand clearly” in more literary or formal use.
components: The character 了 is written as ⿱乛亅: the top stroke 乛 is a bending hook-like stroke, and the bottom part 亅 is a vertical line with a small hook. Historically it’s a simple pictographic form that later took on abstract grammatical functions. It doesn’t contain a clear semantic radical; instead, its meaning comes from long usage in the language, not from its parts. For learners, you can think of the top hook (乛) as a ‘turn’ or ‘change’, and the lower hook (亅) as a ‘stop’ or ‘finish’, together hinting at “something has turned and come to an end,” which fits the idea of completion or change of state.
